overview: This subject will provide practical insights into the role of science and scientific thinking within business, and the successful application of this perspective, along with communication and business tools, to work environments. Students will be assigned to syndicate groups to address a practical industry challenge/issue which has been identified by industry. In addressing this task students will draw upon their discipline knowledge and the skills provided in the professional tools subjects. On commencement of the project, students will be required to spend a specific time in the business setting and to then maintain regular contact with the business, as well as the project supervisor, across the duration of the subject.
ilo: Integrate evidence, scientific knowledge and professional skills to develop effective solutions to industry-based problems;
Devise and deliver a set of outcomes formulated in collaboration with industry;
Appraise and critique an industry-based project and articulate its expected impact in the context of broader organisational goals; and
Create a productive professional partnership with peers and industry.
generic_skills: leading and participating in teams and managing, persuading and influencing others;
demonstrating the breadth of knowledge gained in an inter-disciplinary approach;
applying advanced scientific analysis, communication and leadership in business and professional practice;
the exercise of critical judgement and rigorous and independent thinking;
accounting for their decisions and adopting a problem solving approach;
high level written report presentation skills;
oral communication and presentation skills; and

Prerequisites.content: CodeNameTeaching periodCredit PointsSKIL90004Project Management in ScienceSemester 2 (On Campus - Parkville)12.5

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: Attendance at a minimum of six out of eight of workshops throughout the teaching period.
assessment.hurdle: Students must attend a minimum of six out of eight 2-hour workshops in weeks 1-8 of Semester 1.

assessment.brief: Group Charter Agreement (4 students per group) with Industry Partner as to project specifications (250 words per person)
Group Project Plan (4 students per group) - up to 1800 words plus appendices
Group Project (4 students per group) - progress oral presentation
Final Group Report (4 students per group) - 4000 words (1000 words per student) plus appendices
assessment.timing: At the end of the final week of Semester 2

assessment.brief: Final Individual Report, 3,500 words plus appendices
assessment.timing: At the end of the first week of the exam period in Semester 2

assessment.brief: Industry Partner Assessment of group performance, via final group 20-minute presentation
assessment.timing: At the end of the final week of Semester 2

date_times.contact_hours: Eight 2-hour workshops (16 hours total), a minimum of 48 hours devoted to industry project supervisor meetings, syndicate group discussions, and attending Faculty of Science industry events/seminars, a minimum of 10 hours per week of effort towards the industry project and 36 hours of self-directed study.
